questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The growth curve of bacterial population in lab is plotted against time. What will be the shape of graph?
questions.explanation:
Semilog of per minute growing bacterium
when plotted against time, would yield
ascending straight line.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which statement is correct for bacterial transduction?

options.content: Transfer of some genes from one bacteria to another bacteria through virus.
Transfer of genes from one bacteria to another bacteria by conjugation.
Bacteria obtained its DNA directly from mother cell.
Bacteria obtained DNA from other external source.

questions.explanation:
In transduction, genetic material of one bacterial cell goes to other bacterial cell by agency of bacteriophages or phages (viruses, infecting bacteria).

Transduction was first of all reported in Salmonella typhimurium by Zinder and Lederberg (1952). Transduction is used for gene mapping and analysis in bacteria and also for strain construction

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In five kingdom system, the main basis of classification is
questions.explanation:
The five kingdom classification is a mode of classification based on the following criteria.
• Complexity of cell structure
• Complexity of body structure
• Modes of nutrition
• Ecological life styles
• Phylogenetic relationship

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following secretes toxins during storage conditions of crop plants?
questions.explanation:
Aspergillus flavus produces carcinogenic
fungus toxin (Aflatoxin) during storage
condition of crop plant.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Choose the correct sequence of stages of growth curve for bacteria.
questions.explanation:
The growth curve for bacteria is sigmoid.
First phase is the phase of slow growthLag phase. Second phase is the period of
accelerated growth - Log phase. Third phase
is the phase when growth rate becomes
stable - Stationary phase. Finally growth rate
declines.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which fungal disease spreads by seed and flowers?
questions.explanation:
Ustilago causes loose smut of wheat, as a
result the grain and flower get converted into
powdered mass.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In bacteria, plasmid is
questions.explanation:
In addition to the nucleoid, bacterial cytoplasm normally contains many small, separate pieces of DNA, called plasmids. These circular DNA units are 1/100 the size of the main nuclear DNA (nucleoid) and are also not enclosed in a membrane structure.

When found in cytoplasm, entirely independent of the bacterial chromosome, they replicate autonomously. Sometimes it becomes integrated into the main DNA and replicates with it. During conjugation, the plasmids, sometimes called episomes, help in the transfer of the genetic material between different bacteria. It may carry some genes of resistance to a variety of antibiotics.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Some bacteria are able to grow in streptomycin containing medium due to
questions.explanation:
Normally bacteria cannot survive in
antibiotic containing medium but if it does so it
must have acquired resistance against that
antibiotic. These are well adapted to grow in
streptomycin containing medium and thus are more
evolved. So due to natural selection only the more
evolved and better adapted species is able to
survive.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following is without exception in angiosperms?
questions.explanation:
Vesselless angiosperms are Wintera, Trochodendron etc. Secondary growth is absent in some angiosperms. Angiospermic plants are autotrophic in nutrition. But some angiosperms are heterotrophic in nutrition. The 4 special modes of nutrition and their examples include:
(i) Saprophytic : e.g. Neottia, Monotropa.
(ii) Symbiotic – e.g. Mycorrhiza-between fungus and roots of higher plants.
(iii) Parasitic – Cuscuta.
(iv) Insectivorous plant – Nepenthes. Double fertilization is characteristic of all angiosperms.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following plants produces seeds but not flowers?
questions.explanation:
Maize, mint and peepal are flowering
plants or angiosperms but Pinus is a
gymnosperm in which seeds are produced
but flowers are not produced or seeds are not
enclosed in flowers.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In which of the following animals nerve cell is present but brain is absent?
questions.explanation:
Hydra which belongs to the Phylum Coelenterata has nerve cells but no brain. Its nervous system consists of nerve cells and their processes. Sensory cells are also present. Sponges do not have nerve cells, they lack nervous system.

Earthworm (annelida) has nervous system consisting of a circumenteric nerve ring and a solid, double, midventral nerve cord with ganglia. Cockroach (arthropoda) has the nervous system as that of earthworm.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In which of the following animals dimorphic nucleus is found?
questions.explanation:
Dimorphic nucleus means two types of nuclei are present in P. caudatum – large macronucleus and small micronucleus. The macronucleus is roughly kidney-shaped and with inconspicuous nuclear membrane. Macronucleus is the somatic or vegetative nucleus and controls the day-to-day metabolic activities of the cell. The micronucleusis lodged in a depression on the surface of the macronucleus.

It is usually spherical, with a nuclear membrane and with diploid number of chromosomes. It controls the reproductive activities of the organism. Amoeba, Trypanosoma and Plasmodium have only one nucleus.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In which of the following, notochord is present in embryonic stage?
questions.explanation:
Presence of notochord in any stage of the
life cycle is a major chordate characteristic.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In protozoa like Amoeba and Paramecium, the organ for osmoregulation is
questions.explanation:
The function of contractile vacuole is
osmoregulatory. Water in freshwater protozoa enters
the organism by endosmosis and during feeding. If
the organism does not possess a mechanism to get
rid of this excess water, it will swell to the point of
rupture and dissolution. The mechanism which is
assumed to effect water regulation is the contractile
vacuole. The vacuole periodically increases in volume
(diastole) to get filled with water and contracts
(systole) to discharge its water content to the
surrounding environment.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Geocarpic fruit is
questions.explanation:
Geocarpic fruits are those which
develop underground. Groundnut is the fruit
which develops underground, onion and
carrot also occur within the soil but onion
is a modified stem while carrot is a modified
root.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Edible part in mango is
questions.explanation:
Mango (Mangifera indica) of Family
Anacardiaceae is a drupe. The edible part in mango
is mesocarp.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following is a reducing sugar?
questions.explanation:
All those sugars which have free aldehyde
or ketone group are called reducing sugars. These are
able to reduce cupric ions (Cu<sup>+2</sup>) into cuprous ions
(Cu<sup>+</sup>). Sucrose, starch are non-reducing sugars.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Lipids are insoluble in water because lipid molecules are
questions.explanation:
Water attracting molecules are called hydrophilic. Water repelling molecules are called hydrophobic. Amino acids simultaneously carry positive and negative charges. Such substances are called zwitter ions. Lipids are compounds of C, H, O but the ratio of H and O is more than 2 : 1, that is, the ratio of oxygen is lesser than carbohydrates. Lipids are insoluble in water but soluble in non-polar solvents such as benzene, chloroform etc.

The most common lipid found in a cell is phospholipid. It contains a hydrophilic (polar) head and a hydrophobic (non- polar tail).

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Mitotic spindle is mainly composed of which protein?
questions.explanation:
A spindle of fine fibres begins to develop
during prophase. It consists of microtubules which
are made of protein called tubulin and certain other
associated proteins. These delicate fibres radiate from
the centriole and constitute aster.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Best material for the study of mitosis in laboratory is
questions.explanation:
Mitosis occurs both in somatic cells as well
as in germ cells of the gonads. In plants mitosis occurs
in the meristematic cells of root tip or shoot tip. These
cells divide at a faster rate. So the root tip shows active
cell division and are used in the laboratory to study
mitosis. For studying meiosis young anthers are used.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In photosynthersis energy from light reaction to dark reaction is transferred in the form of
questions.explanation:
ATP molecules produced in the light
reaction are used in the dark reaction to fix
CO<sub>2</sub> to form organic compounds.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following absorb light energy for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation:
Each pigment has its own absorption
spectrum, chlorophyll absorbs light energy
in blue and red region.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which pigment absorbs the red and far-red light?
questions.explanation:
Phytochrome has a light absorbing or light detecting portion (the chromophore) attached to small protein of about 1,24,000 daltons. Phytochrome occurs in 2 forms, i.e., PR and PFR (i.e., red light and far red light absorbing forms) and these 2 forms are interconvertible.

Cytochromes are electron transferring proteins. They contain iron porphyrin or copper porphyrin as prosthetic groups. Chlorophyll is the fundamental green pigment of photosynthesis. It is localised in the chloroplasts. Carotenoids are lipid compounds and they are yellow, orange, purple, etc. in colour. These are found in higher plants red algae, green algae, fungi and photosynthetic bacteria.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Organisms which obtain energy by the oxidation of reduced inorganic compounds are called
questions.explanation:
Chemoautotrophs are organisms that are
capable of manufacturing their organic food utilising
chemical energy released in oxidation of some
inorganic substances. The process of manufacture of
food in such organisms is called chemosynthesis. It
includes some aerobic bacteria. Photoautotroph obtain
energy for their synthesis of food from light.
Fungi living on dead or decaying plant or animal
remains and also growing on dung of herbivores are
saprophytes.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: How many ATP molecules are produced by aerobic oxidation of one molecule of glucose?
questions.explanation: Energy gain in one complete cycle of aerobic respiration is : In aerobic respiration complete oxidation of one glucose molecule produces 38 ATP molecules. But the number of ATP molecules so produced may vary depending upon the mode of entry of NADH2 in the mitochondria. If the electrons of NADH2 are accepted by malate then each molecule of NADH2 yields 3 ATP molecules and the total would be 38 ATP molecules. But if the electrons of NADH2 are accepted by FAD it yields only 2 ATP molecules making the total of 36 ATP molecules. This type of shuttle occurs in most of the eukaryotic cells.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Dwarfness can be controlled by treating the plant with
questions.explanation:
Gibberellins helps in the reversal of dwarfism
in many genetically dwarf plants. External supply of
Gibberellic acid causes rapid elongation of growth.
E.g., rosette plant of sugarbeet when treated with GA3
undergoes marked longitudinal growth of axis.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Seed dormancy is due to the
questions.explanation:
Ethylene breaks dormancy of different
plants. Abscisic acid induces dormancy in
seeds, buds and underground storage organs.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Impulse of heart beat originates from
questions.explanation:
SA node is called the pacemaker
because it initiates the cardiac impulse. AV
node receives the impulse from the SA node
and transmits it to the ventricles.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following statements is true for lymph?
questions.explanation:
Lymph is a colourless vascular connective tissue derived from tissue fluid. RBCs
and platelets are absent. Only leucocytes and
floating amoeboid lymphocytes are present.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: What will happen if ligaments are torn?

options.content: Bones will move freely at joint and no pain.
Bone less movable at joint and pain.

questions.explanation:
Ligments are specialised connective
tissues which connect bones together, hence
if they are cut or broken the bone will be
come unfixed.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which cartilage is present at the end of long bones?
questions.explanation:
Cartilage is an important component of
skeleton. It consists of a firm matrix containing
collagen and elastin fibres and cells in fluid-filled
lacunae. Cartilage has many types. Elastic cartilage
occurs in the pinna and external auditory canal of the
ear, epiglottis, Eustachian tubes and tip of the nose
to make these organs flexible. Fibrous cartilage is very
strong yet has a degree of flexibility. It is found in the
intervertebral discs where it acts as a cushion and in
pubic symphysis where it allows parturition without
damage to the girdle. Hyaline cartilage occurs in
sternal ribs where it allows expansion of chest during
inspiration. It also forms the tracheal and bronchial
rings and supports larynx and nasal septum and also
at the end of long bones.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following statement is correct for node of Ranvier of nerve?

options.content: Both neurilemma and myelin sheath are discontinuous

questions.explanation:
Neurons are the chief functional units
of the nervous system. An ordinary neuron
has a soma or cyton and a long thread called
axon which is enclosed in a multilayered
myelin sheath, made by Schwann cells.
The myelin sheath is interrupted at the
spaces between schwann cells to form gaps.
These gaps are called Nodes of Ranvier.
These nodes and the myelin sheath create
condition that speed up the nerve impulses.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: When both ovaries are removed from rat then which hormone is decreased in blood?
questions.explanation:
Ovary secretes two hormones. Estrogen
before ovulation and progesterone after ovulation.
Oxytocin, prolaction are pituitary hormones and
gonadotropin releasing factor is secreted by
hypothlalamus of brain to stimulate pituitary for the
secretion of gonadotropic hormones.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Adrenaline directly affects on
questions.explanation:
Adrenaline directly affects the SA node to
increase rate of heartbeat. Adrenaline prepares the
body for emergency reactions like fight and flight.
Thus there is increase in heart rate, breathing rate,
blood pressure, glucose level in blood, peripheral
circulation, etc.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Mainly which type of hormones control the menstrual cycle in human beings?
questions.explanation:
Estrogens are steroid hormones
secreted by growing ovarian follicles.
During menstrual cycle a negative feedback
prevents the secretion of estrogen. FSH
stimulates maturation of Graafian follicles.
LH stimulates ovulation and development of
corpus luteum.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Acromegaly is caused by
questions.explanation:
Acromegaly is caused by excess of STH
(somatotrophic hormone), released by anterior lobe
of pituitary after adolescence. The bones of the lower
jaw and limbs become abnormally enlarge but the
body does not attain a giant stature. Excess of
thyroxine causes cretinism and myxoedema. Excess
of adrenaline causes increased BMR (Basal Metabolic
Rate), heart beat, excitement, etc.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In angiosperms pollen tube liberate their male gametes into the
questions.explanation:
On reaching of pollen tube inside the
embryo sac, the 2 male gametes are discharged
through a sub-terminal pore in pollen tube. The
contents of pollen tube are discharged in the
synergid and the pollen tube does not grow beyond
it in the embryo sac. Further the cytoplasm of
pollen tube is restricted to chalazal end of this
synergid cell.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In angiosperm all the four microspores of tetrad are covered by a layer which is formed by
questions.explanation:
Each microspore or pollen is having a two layered wall. Outer layer is thick tough cuticularised called exine, which is chiefly composed of a material called ‘sporopollenin’. Inner layer is thin, delicate and smooth called intine, which is made of pectocellulose.

Exine is not uniform but is thin at one or more places in the form of germ pores. Whereas intine made of pectocellulose covers the entire surface of pollen grains.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: What is the direction of micropyle in anatropous ovule?
questions.explanation:
In anatropous, ovule gets inverted and
micropyle is on the lower side. It is the most
common type of ovule. In orthotropous ovule
micropyle is upward. This is the presentive
type of ovule.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: What is true for cleavage : -
questions.explanation:
During cleavage, the zygote divides
repeatedly to convert the large cytoplasmic mass into
a large number of small blastomeres. It involves cell
division without growth in size because cells continue
to be retained within the zona pellucida. However,
cell size decreases during cleavage.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
In a population, unrestricted reproductive capacity
is called as -
questions.explanation:
Carrying capacity refers to the maximum
number of individuals that can be sustained
by the environment. Birth rate refers to
number of births per unit population.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which of the following is the example of
pleiotropy ?
questions.explanation:
Pleiotropic gene is such a gene which has a
wider effect on phenotype i.e., it controls several
phenotypic traits. Sickle cell anaemia is considered to
be caused by one such pleiotropic gene. It is caused
due to mutation in $$\beta $$-globin gene of haemoglobin.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
There are three genes a, b and c. The percentage
of crossing over between a and b is 20%, b and c
is 28% and a and c is 8%. What is the sequence
of genes on chromosome
questions.explanation:
a – b = 20%, b – c = 28%, a – c = 8%


Percent crossing over between two genes is proportional to the distance between them.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
On selfing a plant of F<sub>1</sub> generation with
genotype “AABbCC”,the genotypic ratio in
F<sub>2</sub> generation will be
questions.explanation:
Selfing is the process of fertilisation with
polar or male gametes of the same individual.
AABbCC will produce two type of gametes ABC and
AbC. Thus, in F<sub>2</sub>
 generation three genotypes will be
obtained. These are AABBCC, AABbCC and
AAbbCC in the ratio of 1 : 2 : 1. Phenotypically
AABBCC and AABbCC are same. So the phenotypic
ratio in F<sub>2</sub>
 generation will be 3 : 1.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
A diseased man marries a normal woman. They
get three daughter and five sons. All the
daughter were diseased and sons were normal.
The gene of this disease is : -
questions.explanation:
Sex linked disorders follow criss-cross
inheritance pattern that affected father passes
it on to their daughters. The daughters receive
one of their X - chromosome from their
fathers.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: A gene said to be dominant if : -

options.content: It expressed only in heterozygous condition

It express it's effect only in homozygous
stage
It never expressed in any condition

It expressed both in homozygous and
heterozygous condition

questions.explanation:
Dominant factor is an allele or Mendelian
factor which expressess itself in the hybrid
(heterozygous) as well as in homozygous state. It is
denoted by capital letter.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following is a correct match -
questions.explanation:
Down’s syndrome (Mongolian Idiocy, Mongolism) is caused by the presence of an extra chromosome number 21. Sickle cell anaemia is not a sex linked (i.e., X linked) disease but an autosomally inherited recessive trait.
Haemophilia is X-linked but not holandric/Y-linked. Parkinson’s disease is a degenerative disease. It is not at all hereditary.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
In a DNA percentage of thymine is 20% then
what is the percentage of guanine : -
questions.explanation:
In a DNA, the percentage of thymine is 20%.
So, as it pairs with adenine, it is also 20%. So the
guanine and cytosine together forms 60% of DNA
and hence, guanine is 30%.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Jacob and Monad studied lactose metabolism in
E.Coli and proposed operon concept. Operon
concept applicable for :
questions.explanation:
Gene regulation of eukaryotes is
complex as compared to that of prokaryotes.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Transformation experiment was first performed
on which bacteria : -
questions.explanation:
Transformation involves transfer of genetic
material of one bacterial cell into another bacterial
cell by some unknown mechanism and it converts one
type of bacterium into another type. This was first
studied by Griffith (1928) in Diplococcus pneumoniae
and hence is known as Griffith effect.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
In E. Coli, during lactose metabolism repressor
binds to : -
questions.explanation: In the lac operon of E.coli due to the activity of regulator gene synthesis of repressor molecules occurs. These repressor molecules get attached to the operator gene and thus check mRNA synthesis and because of this no protein synthesis occurs.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Exon part of m-RNAs have code for : -
questions.explanation:
DNA transcribes to form mRNA. Its function
is to carry coded information from DNA for the
synthesis of proteins. The RNA consists of a coding
region called exon and non-coding region called
introns. The exons are thus the functional part that
have code for proteins.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which of the following enzymes are used to join
bits of DNA ?
questions.explanation:
Ligases are used to join bits of DNA.
Primase is an RNA polymerase, used to initiate DNA
synthesis. DNA polymerase enzyme catalyses the
synthesis of DNA. Endonuclease, causes the splicing
of the intron carrying the coding sequence of the same
endonuclease.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which of the following reunites the exon
segments after RNA splicing ?
questions.explanation:
RNA polymerase enzyme catalyses the
synthesis of RNA. It is single in prokaryotes. There
are three types of RNA polymerases in eukaryotes– I
for 28S, 18S and 5.8S RNA, II for mRNA and snRNA
and III for tRNA, 5S RNA and scRNA. Primase is an
RNA polymerase that is used to initiate DNA
synthesis. RNA ligase reunites the exon segment after
RNA splicing.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Out of 64 codons, 61 codons code for 20 types
of amino acid it is called : -
questions.explanation:
Out of 64 codons, only 3 signify stop
codons. There are more than one codon
for most of the amino acids, the genetic
code is non-over lapping. Three successive
nucleotides or bases code for only one
amino acid wobbling refers to the third base
degeneracy.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Change in sequence of nucleotide in DNA is
called as -
questions.explanation:
A mutation involves a change in the
sequence of nucleotides in a nucleic acid molecule.
This change will express itself in the form of a change
in the sequence of aminoacids in the protein molecule
synthesized through the information, encoded in
nucleic acid segment. Therefore mutations at
molecule level can be studied both by the study of
the sequence of amino acids in a protein and also by
the study of sequence of nucleotides in a segment of
nucleic acid.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Cause of mimicry is -
questions.explanation:
Mimicry is resemblance of an organism
to its natural surroundings, a non living object
or another organism for concealing itself from
its natural predators or preys.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which of the following is important for
speciation ?
questions.explanation:
Seasonal isolation refers to the
differences in season of breeding that
can isolate two varieties. Behavioural or
ethological isolation refers to differences
in behaviour like courtship rituals etc. to
prevent mating. Mechanical isolation refers 
to the differences in the position, size and
structure of animal genitalia which prevent
reproductive contact and thus bring about
isolation. Reproductive isolation is the
prevention of interbreeds between the
population of two different species.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: There is no life on moon due to the absence of -
questions.explanation:
Water is the most essential material to
survive. One can thrive without O<sub>2</sub>
 (anaerobic
bacteria) and light and in a wide range of temperature
but one cannot live without water which is the most
important component of the body (about 90% of
plasma consists of water) and life was originated from
abiogenetic materials in water.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which of the following are homologous organs ?

options.content:
Wings of birds & Pectoral fins of
fish

questions.explanation:
Homologous organs have same basic
structure and origin but they differ in their
external appearance and function.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Genetic drift oparates in : -

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Sequence of which of the following is used to
know the phylogeny ?
questions.explanation:
Carl Woese came up with the theory of life
based on his discovery that the genes encoding
ribosomal RNA are ancient and distributed over all
lineages of life with little or no gene transfer.
Therefore, rRNA are commonly recommended as
molecular clocks to the phylogeny.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
In which condition, the gene ratio remains
constant for any species population ?
questions.explanation:
Mutation is any random sudden
heritable change occurring in the genetic
material. Sexual selection refers to selection
of a mate by an organism.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
According to fossils which discovered up to
present time, origin and evolution of man was
started from
questions.explanation:
The common ancestor of both ape and man is Dryopithecus – a 20 million years old fossil discovered from Africa. Austroalopithecus also lived in Africa between 6 million to 1 million years ago. The genus Homo evolved 2 million years ago from one of such Australopithecines in Africa and then only moved out of the continent.
The first such Homo lived throughout Asia, some parts of Europe and Africa. But obviously its evolution took place in Africa.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In which era reptiles were dominant ?
questions.explanation:
Mesozoic era is the era during which reptiles
were dominant. It includes three periods : Triassic
(240 million years ago), Jurassic (195 million years
ago) and Cretaceous (135 million years ago). Origin
of dinosaurs occurred during triassic period. During
Jurassic period, lizards, crocodiles and alligators
originated. Dinosaurs became large and reptiles were
dominant during this period. During cretaceous
period, dinosaurs got extinct.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Cancerous cells can easily be destroyed by
radiations due to : -
questions.explanation:
The ability of radiations to kill cells is
highest in the tissue with the highest number
of dividing cells. Tumour cells proliferate
rapidly. Hence, tumours are killed more
rapidly by radiations.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
If a diploid cell is treated with colchicine then it
becomes : -
questions.explanation:
Colchicine inhibits spindle formation,
due to which chromatids are unable to
separate during anaphase which results in
doubling of chromosomes. So, if a diploid
cell is treated with colchicine, there is
doubling of chromosomes and it becomes
tetraploid,. Its an alkaloid obtained from
Colchicum autumnale.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
What is the reason of formation of embryoid
from pollen grain in tissue culture medium  ?
questions.explanation:
Cellular totipotency is the ability, shown
by many living cells to form all types of tissue
that constitute the mature organism.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which of the following crops have been brought
to India from New world ?
questions.explanation:
Cashewnut, potato, rubber crops have
been brought to India from New world.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which bacteria is utilized in Gober gas plant ?
questions.explanation:
Methanobacillus (methanogen) occurs in
marshes and also in dung. It produces CH<sub>4</sub>
gas under anaerobic condition and is utilized
in gobar gas plant.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
During the formation of bread it becomes
porous due to release of CO<sub>2</sub> by the action of : -
questions.explanation:
Yeast carry out fermentation, releasing
CO<sub>2</sub> making bread soft and porous. Hence,
Saccharomyces is referred to as baker’s yeast.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Manipulation of DNA in genetic engineering
became possible due to the discovery of : -
questions.explanation:
DNA restriction endonuclease are important class of restriction exonucleases, class II, which cut double-stranded DNA molecules only at sites characterized by a specific nucleotide sequence. Restriction enzymes are isolated from bacterial cells and are tools for molecular biologists. Several hundred restriction enzymes are now known, each with a specific sequence requirement dictating where it will cut DNA. Some, such as

Hind III, make staggered cuts leaving ‘sticky ends’, three nucleotides long protruding on one strand from each severed terminus; others make clean cuts in both strands at the same place and thus generate ‘blunt ends’. Digesting DNA with a restriction enzyme therefore creates a characteristic set of fragments, which can be isolated by electrophoresis and subsequently analysed.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: What is true for individuals of same species ?
questions.explanation:
Individuals of the same species can
interbreed. No two individuals share the
same ecological niche.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which type of association is found in between
entomophilous flower and pollinating agent ?
questions.explanation:
Co-evolution can occur in any
interspecific relationship like symbiosis or
mutualism. The relation between an entomophilous
flower and pollinating insect shows co-evolved
mutualism. In this the plant depends exclusively on
the insect for pollination and the insect relies on the
plant for food.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Two different species can not live for long duration
in the same niche or habitat. This law is : -
questions.explanation:
Interspecific competition is rivalry
amongst members of different species. The severity
of competition depends upon similarity in the
requirement of food and shelter. Every type of
organism has a particular niche, no two organisms
can live in same niche. One of the two is eliminated.
This phenomenon is called Gause hypothesis of
competitive exclusion.

questions.explanation:
Trophic structure of ecosystem is a type

food level is called trophic level and the graphical
representation of trophic structure of ecosystem
constitutes ecological pyramids. The green plants
are producers and represent the first trophic level
(T<sub>1</sub>). So bamboo plant is the first trophic level (T<sub>1</sub>).

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Wildlife is continuously decreasing.
What is the main reason of this ?
questions.explanation:
Wildlife refers to all living organisms (terrestrial, aquatic and aerial) living in all possible natural habitats of their own, other than the cultivated plants and domesticated animals. Thus “wildlife” does not exist only in jungles and are hunted down but wild life includes even the migrating birds, turtles, coral reefs, microorganisms, insects, fishes, etc.

Several hundred organisms are endangered or on the verge of extinction. The reasons are deforestation, pollution, killing, over exploitation etc. The most important among them is deforestation or destruction of their natural habitat because it will affect the species (flora and fauna) of complete area and not only the few organisms. The natural habitat may be destroyed by man for his settlements, grazing grounds, agriculture, mining, industries, dam building etc. As a consequence of this, the species must adapt to the changes, move elsewhere or may succumb to predation, starvation or disease, and eventually dies.

Melanin, a pigment present in skin, protects it from
harmful effects of UV rays. People living in tropics
have more melanin in their skin which is an adaptation
to protect themselves from harmful UV rays. Melanin
cannot protect from infrared rays and X-rays.

questions.content: Heat of combustion $$\Delta $$H<sup>o</sup> for C<sub>(s)</sub>, H<sub>2(g)</sub> and CH<sub>4(g)</sub> are $$-$$ 94, $$-$$ 68 and $$-$$213 kcal/mol, then $$\Delta $$H<sup>o</sup> for C<sub>(s)</sub> + 2H<sub>2(g)</sub> $$ \to $$ CH<sub>4(g)</sub> is
questions.explanation:
C(s) + 2H2(g) $$ \to $$ CH4(g), $$\Delta $$Ho = ?

C(s) + O2(g) → CO2(g), $$\Delta $$H = – 94 kcal/mol ....(1)

H2(g) + $${1 \over 2}$$O2(g) $$ \to $$ H2O(g), $$\Delta $$H = – 68 kcal/mol ....(2)

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) $$ \to $$ CO2(g) + H2O(l), $$\Delta $$H = – 213 kcal/mol ....(3)

Performing (1) + 2 × (2) – (3)

$$\Delta $$Ho = [– 94 – 2(68)] – (–213) kcal/mol

= [– 94 – 136] + 213 k cal/mol

= – 230 + 213 = – 17 kcal/mol

w = q = nRT $$ \times $$ 2.303 $$\log {{{v_2}} \over {{v_1}}}$$

= 2RT $$ \times $$ 2.303 $$\log {{{20}} \over {{2}}}$$

= 2 × 2 × T × 2.303 × 1 = 9.2 T

Entropy change, $$\Delta $$S = $${q \over T}$$ = $${{9.2T} \over T}$$ = 9.2 cal/mol K

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The hypothetical complex chloro diaquatriammine cobalt(III) chloride can be represented as
questions.explanation:
The hypothetical complex "chloro diaquatriammine cobalt(III) chloride" can be broken down as follows :

  • "chloro" indicates the presence of a chloride ion (Cl⁻) as a ligand.

  • "diaqua" indicates the presence of two water molecules (H₂O) as ligands.

  • "triammine" indicates the presence of three ammonia molecules (NH₃) as ligands.

  • "cobalt(III)" indicates that cobalt is in the +3 oxidation state.

  • The additional "chloride" at the end suggests the presence of chloride ions outside the coordination sphere, likely as counterions.

Given this, let's analyze the options :

  • Option A - [CoCl(NH₃)₃(H₂O)₂]Cl₂ : This matches the description. It has one chloro ligand, three ammonia ligands, two water ligands, and two chloride ions as counterions, with cobalt in the +3 oxidation state.

  • Option B - [Co(NH₃)₃(H₂O)Cl₃] : Incorrect, as it suggests three chloride ligands inside the coordination sphere, which is not specified in the name.

  • Option C - [Co(NH₂)₃(H₂O)₂Cl] : Incorrect, as NH₂ is not the same as NH₃ (ammonia), and it also suggests a different ligand arrangement.

  • Option D - [Co(NH₃)₃(H₂O)₃]Cl₃ : Incorrect, as it has three water molecules instead of two and lacks the chloro ligand inside the coordination sphere.

Therefore, the correct representation is Option A - [CoCl(NH₃)₃(H₂O)₂]Cl₂.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An object of mass 3 kg is at rest. Now a force of $$\overrightarrow F $$ = 6t<sup>2</sup> $$\widehat i$$ + 4t $$\widehat j$$ is applied on the object then velocity of object at t = 3 sec. is
questions.explanation:
Mass (m) = 3 kg, force (F) = $$6{t^2}\widehat i + 4t\widehat j$$

$$ \therefore $$ acceleration
$$a = F/m = {{6{t^2}\widehat i + 4t\widehat j} \over 3} = 2{t^2}\widehat i + {4 \over 3}t\widehat j$$

Now, $$a = {{dv} \over {dt}} = 2{t^2}\widehat i + {4 \over 3}t\widehat j$$

$$dv = \left( {2{t^2}\widehat i + {4 \over 3}t\widehat j} \right)dt$$

$$ \therefore v = \int\limits_0^3 {\left( {2{t^2}\widehat i + {4 \over 3}t\widehat j} \right)} dt$$

= $$\left. {{2 \over 3}{t^3}\widehat i + {4 \over 6}{t^2}\widehat j} \right|_0^3 = 18\widehat i + 6\widehat j$$

has no component in vertical (component of a vector
at a direction of 90<sup>o</sup> = 0) direction. Hence they will
reach the ground simultaneously.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A lift of mass 1000 kg which is moving with acceleration of 1 m/s<sup>2</sup> in upward direction, then the tension developed in string which is connected to lift is
questions.explanation:
For a lift which is moving in upward direction with an acceleration a, the tension T developed in the string connected to the lift is given by

T = m (g + a).

Here m = 1000 kg, a = 1 m/s2, g = 9.8 m/s2

$$ \therefore $$ T = 1000(9.8 + 1) = 10,800 N.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A block of mass 10 kg placed on rough horizontal surface having coefficient of friction m = 0.5,  if a horizontal force of 100 N acting on it then acceleration of the block will be
questions.explanation:
m = 10 kg, R = mg

$$ \therefore $$ Frictional force = fk

= $${\mu _k}R = {\mu _k}mg$$

= 0.5 × 10 × 10

= 50 N [g = 10 m/sec2]

$$ \therefore $$ Net force acting on the body = F = P – fk
= 100 – 50 = 50 N.

$$ \therefore $$ Acceleration of the block = a = F/m
= 50/10 = 5 m/sec2 .

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If kinetic energy of a body is increased by 300% then percentage change in momentum will be :
questions.explanation:
Let m be the mass of the body and v1 and v2 be the initial and final velocities of the body respectively.

$$ \therefore $$ Initial kinetic energy = $${1 \over 2}mv_1^2$$

Final kinetic energy = $${1 \over 2}mv_2^2$$

Initial kinetic energy is increased 300% to get the final kinetic energy.

$$ \therefore $$ $${1 \over 2}mv_2^2 = {1 \over 2}\left( {1 + {{300} \over {100}}} \right)mv_1^2$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ v2 = 2v1 or v2/v1 = 2 ... (i)

Initial momentum = p1 = mv1

Final momentum = p2 = mv2

$$ \therefore $$$${{{p_2}} \over {{p_1}}} = {{m{v_2}} \over {m{v_1}}} = {{{v_2}} \over {{v_1}}} = 2$$

$$ \therefore $$ $${p_2} = 2{p_1} = \left( {1 + {{100} \over {100}}} \right){p_1}$$

So momentum has increased 100%.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A rod of length is 3 m and its mass acting per unit length is directly proportional to distance x from one of its end then its centre of gravity from that end will be at :
questions.explanation:
Let us consider an elementary length dx at a distance x from one end.

It’s mass = k ·x ·dx

[k = proportionality constant]

Then centre of gravity of the rod xc is given by

$${x_c} = {{\int\limits_0^3 {kxdx.x} } \over {\int\limits_0^3 {kxdx} }} = {{\int\limits_0^3 {{x^2}dx} } \over {\int\limits_0^3 {xdx} }} = {{\left. {{{{x^3}} \over 3}} \right|_0^3} \over {\left. {{{{x^2}} \over 2}} \right|_0^3}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {x_c} = {{{{27} \over 3}} \over {{9 \over 2}}} = 2$$

$$ \therefore $$ Centre of gravity of the rod will be at distance of 2 m from one end.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A point P consider at contact point of a wheel on ground which rolls on ground without slipping then value of displacement of point P when wheel completes half of rotation (if radius of wheel is 1 m)
questions.explanation:
In half rotation point P has moved horizontally.

$${{\pi d} \over 2} = \pi r = \pi \times 1m = \pi \,m$$   $$\left[ \because {radius = 1m} \right]$$

In the same time, it has moved vertically a distance which is equal to its diameter = 2 m.

$$ \therefore $$ Displacement of P = $$\sqrt {{\pi ^2} + {2^2}} = \sqrt {{\pi ^2} + 4} $$ m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A solid sphere of radius R is placed on smooth horizontal surface. A horizontal force F is applied at height h from the lowest point. For the maximum acceleration of centre of mass, which is correct ?

options.content: no relation between h and R.

questions.explanation: Since there is no friction at the contact surface (smooth horizontal surface) there will be no rolling. Hence, the acceleration of the centre of mass of the sphere will be independent of the position of the applied force F. Therefore, there is no relation between h and R.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A disc is rotating with angular speed $$\omega $$. If a child sits on it, what is conserved
questions.explanation:
If external torque is zero, angular momentum remains conserved.
[External torque is zero because the weight of child acts downward]

L = I$$\omega $$ = constant

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A circular disc is to be made by using iron and aluminium so that it acquired maximum moment of inertia about geometrical axis. It is possible with

options.content: aluminium at interior and iron surround to it
iron at interior and aluminium surround to it
using iron and aluminium layers in alternate order
sheet of iron is used at both external surface and aluminium sheet as internal layers.

questions.explanation:
A circular disc may be divided into a large number of circular rings. Moment of inertia of the disc will be the summation of the moments of inertia of these rings about the geometrical axis.

Now, moment of inertia of a circular ring about its geometrical axis is MR2, where M is the mass and R is the radius of the ring.

Since the density (mass per unit volume) for iron is more than that of aluminium, the proposed rings made of iron should be placed at a higher radius to get more value of MR2. Hence to get maximum moment of inertia for the circular disc, aluminium should be placed at interior and iron at the outside.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Unit of Stefan's constant is
questions.explanation: Unit of Stefan’s constant is watt/m<sup>2</sup>K<sup>4</sup>.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Consider two rods of same length and different specific heats (S<sub>1</sub>, S<sub>2</sub>), conductivities (K<sub>1</sub>, K<sub>2</sub>) and area of cross-sections (A<sub>1</sub>, A<sub>2</sub>) and both having temperatures T<sub>1</sub> and T<sub>2</sub> at their ends. If rate of loss of heat due to conduction is equal, then
questions.explanation:
Rate of heat loss in rod 1 = Q1 $$ = {{{K_1}{A_1}\left( {{T_1} - {T_2}} \right)} \over {{l_1}}}$$

Rate of heat loss in rod 2 = Q2 $$ = {{{K_2}{A_2}\left( {{T_1} - {T_2}} \right)} \over {{l_2}}}$$

By problem, Q1 = Q2.

$$ \therefore {{{K_1}{A_1}\left( {{T_1} - {T_2}} \right)} \over {{l_1}}} = {{{K_2}{A_2}\left( {{T_1} - {T_2}} \right)} \over {{l_2}}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ K1A1 = K2A2.   $$\left[ \because{{l_1} = {l_2}} \right]$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For a black body at temperature 727<sup>o</sup>C, its radiating power is 60 watt and temperature of surrounding is 227<sup>o</sup>C. If temperature of black body is changed to 1227<sup>o</sup>C then its radiating power will be
questions.explanation:
Radiating power of a black body

$$ = {E_0} = \sigma \left( {{T^4} - T_0^4} \right)A$$

where $$\sigma $$ is known as the Stefan-Boltzmann constant, A is the surface area of a black body, T is the temperature of the black body and T0 is the temperature of the surrounding.

$$ \therefore $$ 60 = $$\sigma $$(10004 – 5004)    ...(i)

[T = 727oC = 727 + 273 = 1000 K, T0 = 227oC = 500 K].

In the second case, T = 1227oC = 1500 K and let E' be the radiating power.

$$ \therefore $$ E' = $$\sigma $$(15004 – 5004)    ...(ii)

From (i) and (ii) we have

$${{E'} \over {60}} = {{{{1500}^4} - {{500}^4}} \over {{{1000}^4} - {{500}^4}}} = {{{{15}^4} - {5^4}} \over {{{10}^4} - {5^4}}} = {{50000} \over {9375}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $$E' = {{50000} \over {9375}} \times 60 = 320\,W$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Which of the following is best close to an ideal black body?

options.content: a lump of charcoal heated to high temperature.

questions.explanation:
An ideal black body is one which absorbs all the incident radiation without reflecting or transmitting any part of it. Black lamp absorbs approximately 96% of incident radiation.

An ideal black body can be realized in practice by a small hole in the wall of a hollow body (as shown in figure) which is at uniform temperature. Any radiation entering the hollow body through the holes suffers a number of reflections and ultimately gets completely absorbed. This can be facilitated by coating the interior surface with black so that about 96% of the radiation is absorbed at each reflection. The portion of the interior surface opposite to the hole is made conical to avoid the escape of the reflected ray after one reflection.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The Wien's displacement law express relation between

options.content: wavelength corresponding to maximum energy and temperature

questions.explanation: Wien’s displacement law states that the product of absolute temperature and the wavelength at which the emissive power is maximum is constant i.e. $$\lambda _{max}$$ T = constant. Therefore it expresses relation between wavelength corresponding to maximum energy and temperature.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The efficiency of Carnot engine is 50% and temperature of sink is 500 K. If temperature of source is kept constant and its efficiency raised to 60%, then the required temperature of sink will be
questions.explanation:
Efficiency ($$\eta$$) of a carnot engine is given by $$\eta = 1 - {{{T_2}} \over {{T_1}}}$$, where T1 is the temperature of the source and T2 is the temperature of the sink.

Here, T2 = 500 K

$$ \therefore $$ $$0.5 = 1 - {{500} \over {{T_1}}} \Rightarrow {T_1} = 1000K$$

Now, $$\eta = 0.6 = 1 - {{{T_2}'} \over {1000}}$$ (T2' is the new sink temperature)

$$ \Rightarrow {T_2}' = 400\,K$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Displacement between maximum potential energy position and maximum kinetic energy position for a particle executing simple harmonic motion is
questions.explanation:
For a simple harmonic motion between A and B, with O as the mean position, maximum kinetic energy of the particle executing SHM will be at O and maximum potential energy will be at A and B.


$$ \therefore $$ Displacement between maximum potential energy and maximum kinetic energy is $$ \pm a$$.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: When an oscillator completes 100 oscillations its amplitude reduced to $${1 \over 3}$$ of initial value. What will be its amplitude, when it complettes 200 oscillations ?
questions.explanation:
This is a case of damped vibration as the amplitude of vibration is decreasing with time.
Amplitude of vibrations at any instant t is given by $$a = a_0e^{–bt}$$, where $$a_0$$ is the initial amplitude of vibrations and b is the damping constant.

Now, when t = 100T, $$a = a_0/3$$  [T is time period]

Let the amplitude be $$a'$$ at t = 200T.
i.e. after completing 200 oscillations.

$$ \therefore $$ $$a = a_0/3 = a0e^{–100Tb}$$   ...(i)

and $$a' = a_0e^{–200Tb}$$ ...(ii)

From (i), $${1 \over 3} = {e^{ - 100Tb}}$$
$$ \therefore $$ $${e^{ - 200Tb}} = 1/9$$

From (ii), $$a' = {a_0} \times {1 \over 9} = {{{a_0}} \over 9}$$

$$ \therefore $$ The amplitude will be reduced to 1/9 of initial value.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A mass is suspended separately by two different springs in (successive order then time periods is t1 and t2 respectively, If it is connected by both spring as shown in figure then time period is t0 , the correct relation is
questions.explanation:
The time period of a spring mass system as shown in figure 1 is given by $$T = 2\pi \sqrt {m/k} $$, where k is the spring constant.

$$ \therefore $$ $${t_1} = 2\pi \sqrt {m/{k_1}} $$   ...(i)
and $${t_2} = 2\pi \sqrt {m/{k_2}} $$   ...(ii)


Now, when they are connected in parallel as shown in figure 2(a), the system can be replaced by a single spring of spring constant, keff = k1 + k2.
[Since mg = k1x + k2x = keffx]

$$ \therefore $$ $${t_0} = 2\pi \sqrt {m/{k_{eff}}} = 2\pi \sqrt {m/\left( {{k_1} + {k_2}} \right)} $$   ...(iii)

From (i), $${1 \over {t_1^2}} = {1 \over {4{\pi ^2}}} \times {{{k_1}} \over m}$$   ...(iv)

From (ii), $${1 \over {t_2^2}} = {1 \over {4{\pi ^2}}} \times {{{k_2}} \over m}$$   ...(v)

From (ii), $${1 \over {t_0^2}} = {1 \over {4{\pi ^2}}} \times {{{k_1} + {k_2}} \over m}$$   ...(vi)

Now (iv) + (v)

$${1 \over {t_1^2}} + {1 \over {t_2^2}} = {1 \over {4{\pi ^2}m}}\left( {{k_1} + {k_2}} \right) = {1 \over {t_0^2}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $$t_0^{ - 2} = t_1^{ - 2} + t_2^{ - 2}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A wave travelling in positive X-direction with a $$=$$ 0.2 ms<sup>$$-$$2</sup>, velocity = 360 ms<sup>$$-$$1</sup> and $$\lambda $$ $$=$$ 60 m,  then correct expression for the wave is
questions.explanation:
The equation of progressive wave travelling in positive x-direction is given by

$$y = a\sin {{2\pi } \over \lambda }\left( {vt - x} \right)$$

Here a = 0.2 m, v = 360 m/sec, $$\lambda $$ = 60 m

$$ \therefore y = 0.2\sin {{2\pi } \over {60}}\left( {360t - x} \right)$$

$$ = 0.2sin\left[ {2\pi \left( {6t - {x \over {60}}} \right)} \right]$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Identical charges ($$-$$q) are placed at each corners of cube of side b then electrostatic potential energy of charge (+q) which is placed at centre of cube will be
questions.explanation:
There are eight corners of a cube and in each corner there is a charge of (–q). At the centre of the corner there is a charge of (+q). Each corner is equidistant from the centres of the cube and the distance (d) is half of the diagonals of the cube.

Diagonal of the cube = $$\sqrt {{b^2} + {b^2} + {b^2}} = \sqrt 3 b$$

$$ \therefore $$ $$d = \sqrt 3 b/2$$

Now, electric potential energy of the charge (+q) due to a charge (–q) at one corner

U $$ = {{{q_1}{q_2}} \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}r}} = {{\left( { + q} \right) \times \left( { - q} \right)} \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}\left( {\sqrt 3 b/2} \right)}} = - {{{q^2}} \over {2\pi {\varepsilon _0}\left( {\sqrt 3 b} \right)}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ Total electric potential energy due to all the eight identical charges
= $$8U = - {{8{q^2}} \over {2\pi {\varepsilon _0}\sqrt 3 b}} = {{ - 4{q^2}} \over {\sqrt 3 \pi {\varepsilon _0}b}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Some charge is being given to a conductor. Then its potential is

options.content: maximum somewhere between surface and centre.

questions.explanation:
Electric field intensity E is zero within a conductor due to charge given to it.

Also, $$E = - {{dV} \over {dx}} \Rightarrow {{dV} \over {dx}} = 0$$   (inside the conductor)

$$ \therefore $$ V = constant. [V is potential]

So potential remains same throughout the conductor.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For a cell terminal potential difference is 2.2V when circuit is open and reduce to 1.8 V when cell is connected to a resistance of R = 5 $$\Omega $$. Determine internal resistance of cell (r)
questions.explanation:
Terminal potential difference is 2.2 V when circuit is open.

$$ \therefore $$ e.m.f. of the cell = E = 2.2 volt

Now, when the cell is connected to the external resistance, circuit current I is given by

$$I = {E \over {R + r}} = {{2.2} \over {5 + r}}$$ ampere, where r is the internal resistance of the cell.

Potential difference across the cell = IR

$$ = {{2.2} \over {5 + r}} \times 5 = 1.8$$

$$ \therefore $$ 5 + r = 11/1.8.

$$ \therefore r = {{11} \over {1.8}} - 5 = {{110 - 90} \over {18}} = {{10} \over 9}\Omega $$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Specific resistance of a conductor increases with

options.content: increase in cross-section and decrease in length

questions.explanation:
Resistance of a conductor is given by R = $$\rho {l \over A}$$, where $$\rho $$ is the specific resistance, $$l$$ is the length and A is the cross-sectional area of the conductor. Now, when $$l$$ = 1 and A = 1, R = $$\rho $$.

So specific resistance or resistivity of a material may be defined as the resistance of a specimen of the material having unit length and unit cross-section. Hence, specific resistance is a property of a material and it will increase with the increase of temperature, but will not vary with the dimensions (length, crosssection) of the conductor.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: To convert a galvanometer into a voltmeter one should connect a

options.content: high resistance in series with galvanometer
low resistance in series with galvanometer
high resistance in parallel with galvanometer
low resistance in parallel with galvanometer.

questions.explanation: For converting galvanometer to voltmeter, a high resistance should be connected in series with  galvanometer.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A charge q moves in a region where electric field and magnetic field both exist, then force on it is
questions.explanation:
Lorentz forece

$$\overrightarrow {{F_L}} = \overrightarrow {{F_e}} + \overrightarrow {{F_m}} $$

= $$q\overrightarrow E + q\left( {\overrightarrow v \times \overrightarrow B } \right)$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The magnetic field of given length of wire for single turn coil at its centre is B then its value for two turns coil for the same wire is
questions.explanation:
B1 = B = $${{{\mu _0}I} \over {2R}}$$

Further, B2 = $${{{\mu _0}\left( {2I} \right)} \over {2r}}$$

Now 2 × 2$$\pi $$r = 2$$\pi $$R or r = R/2

Hence B2 = $$4 \times {{{\mu _0}I} \over {2R}} = 4B$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two bar magnets having same geometry with magnetic moments M and 2M, are firstly placed in such a way that their similar poles are same side then its time period of oscillation is T<sub>1</sub>. Now the polarity of one of the magnet is reversed then time period of oscillation is T<sub>2</sub>, then
questions.explanation:
Time period, T = $$2\pi \sqrt {{I \over {MB}}} $$

$$ \therefore $$ T $$ \propto $$ $${1 \over {\sqrt M }}$$

M1 =2M + M = 3M  

M2 = 2M – M = M

$${{{T_1}} \over {{T_2}}} = \sqrt {{M \over {3M}}} = {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ T2 = $${\sqrt 3 T}$$

$$ \therefore $$ T1 $$<$$ T2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For a series LCR circuit the power loss at resonance is
questions.explanation:
The impedance Z of a series LCR circuit is given by,

Z = $$\sqrt {{R^2} + {{\left( {{X_L} - {X_C}} \right)}^2}} $$

At resonance, XL = XC, hence Z = R.

Let, supply voltage = VR = V

$$ \therefore $$ R.M.S. current, I = $${V \over R}$$

$$ \therefore $$ Power loss = VI = I2R

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The velocity of electromagnetic wave is parallel to
questions.explanation: Since, the direction of propagation of electromagnetic waves is perpendicular to Electric field and Magnetic field. Also electric and magnetic fields perpendicular so, direction of the wave will be parallel to $$\overrightarrow E  \times \overrightarrow B $$.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: What is the cause of Green house effect ?
questions.explanation: Infrared ray is the cause of Green House effect. The glass transmits visible light while infrared rays  are absorbed by plants. Then it emits long infrared rays, which are reflected back by glass.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A bulb is located on a wall. Its image is to be obtained on a parallel wall with the help of convex lens. The lens is placed at a distance d ahead of second wall, then required focal length will be
questions.explanation:
Using the lens formula $${1 \over f} = {1 \over v} - {1 \over u}$$

Given v = d, for equal size image |v| = |u| = d

By sign convention u = -d

$$ \therefore $$ $${1 \over f} = {1 \over d} - {1 \over { - d}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ f = $${d \over 2}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For the given incident ray as shown in figure, the condition of total internal refraction of this ray the required refractive index of prism will be
questions.explanation:
Applying Snell’s law of refraction at A,

$$\mu = {{\sin 45^\circ } \over {\sin r}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ r = $${\sin ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over {\sqrt 2 \mu }}} \right)$$ ....(1)

Applying the condition of total internal reflection at B,

ic = $${\sin ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over \mu }} \right)$$ ..........(2)

where ic is the critical angle.

From figure, r + ic = $${\pi \over 2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${\sin ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over {\sqrt 2 \mu }}} \right) = {\pi \over 2} - {\sin ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over \mu }} \right)$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${\sin ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over {\sqrt 2 \mu }}} \right) = {\cos ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over \mu }} \right)$$ = $${\sin ^{ - 1}}\left( {{{\sqrt {{\mu ^2} - 1} } \over \mu }} \right)$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${{1 \over {\sqrt 2 \mu }} = {{\sqrt {{\mu ^2} - 1} } \over \mu }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${\mu ^2} = 1 + {1 \over 2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\mu = \sqrt {{3 \over 2}} $$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Diameter of human eye lens is 2 mm. What will be the minimum distance between two points to resolve them, which are situated at a distance of 50 meter from eye. The wavelength of light is 5000 $$\mathop A\limits^ \circ  $$
questions.explanation:
For the aparture, limit of resolution :

$${y \over D} \ge {\lambda \over d}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ y $$ \ge $$ $${{\lambda D} \over d}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ y $$ \ge {{5 \times {{10}^{ - 7}} \times 50} \over {2 \times {{10}^{ - 3}}}}$$ $$ \ge $$ 1.25 cm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If particles are moving with same velocity, then which has maximum de Broglie wavelength?
questions.explanation:
de Broglie wavelength for a particle is given by

$$\lambda $$ = $${h \over {mv}}$$

Since all the particles are moving with same velocity, the particle with least mass will have maximum de-Broglie wavelength.

Here $$\beta $$-particles(electrons) has the lowest mass and therefore it has maximum wavelength.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The value of Planck's constant is
questions.explanation: The value of Planck’s constant is 6.63 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>$$-$$34</sup> J-sec.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: When ultraviolet rays incident on metal plate then  photoelectric effect does not occur, it occurs by incidence of
questions.explanation: It occurs by incidence of X-rays.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Which of the following is not the property of cathode rays ?

options.content: It does not deflect in electric field

questions.explanation: Cathode rays are basically negatively charged particles (electrons). If the cathode rays are allowed to pass between two plates kept at a difference of potential, the rays are found to be deflected from the rectilinear path. The direction of deflection shows that the rays carry negative charges.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Which of the following are suitable for the fusion process ?

options.content: element lying in the middle of the periodic table
middle elements, which are lying on binding energy curve.

questions.explanation:
The nuclei of light elements have a lower
binding energy than that for the elements of
intermediate mass. They are therefore less stable;
consequently the fusion of the light elements results
in more stable nucleus.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A deutron is bombarded on <sub>8</sub>O<sup>16</sup> nucleus then $$\alpha $$-particle is emitted. The product nucleus is
questions.explanation:
8O16 + 1H2 $$ \to $$ 7N14 + 2He4

So when a deuteron is bombarded on 8O16 nucleus then an $$\alpha $$-particle (2He4) is emitted and the product nucleus is 7N14.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Number of atom per unit cell in B.C.C.
questions.explanation:
In body-centred cubic (b.c.c.) lattice there are eight atoms at the corners of the cube and one at the centre.

Therefore number of atom per unit cell

= $${1 \over 8} \times 8$$ + 1 = 2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
The given truth table is for which logic gate

              $$\matrix{ A & B & Y \cr 1 & 1 & 0 \cr 0 & 1 & 1 \cr 1 & 0 & 1 \cr 0 & 0 & 1 \cr } $$
questions.explanation: This truth table represents NAND gate.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In a p-n junction

options.content: high potential at n side and low potential at p side
high potential at P side and low potential at n side
p and n both are at same potential

questions.explanation:
For conduction, p-n junction must be
forward biased. For this p-side should be
connected to higher potential and n-side to
lower potential.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: For the given circuit of p-n junction diode which is correct

options.content: in forward bias the voltage across R is V
in reverse bias the voltage across R is V
in forward bias the voltage across R is 2V
in reverse bias the voltage across R is 2V.

questions.explanation:
In forward biasing, the resistance of p-n junction diode is very low to the flow of current. So practically all the voltage will be dropped across the resistance R, i.e. voltage across R will be V.

In reverse biasing, the resistance of p-n junction diode is very high. So the voltage drop across R is zero.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A capacitor of capacity C<sub>1</sub> charged upto V volt and then connected to an uncharged capacitor of capacity C<sub>2</sub>. The final potential difference across each will be
questions.explanation:
Charge Q = C1V
Total capacity of combination (parallel)

C = C1+ C2

$$P.D. = {Q \over C} = {{{C_1}V} \over {{C_1} + {C_2}}}$$
